Emergency Situations Settings Technovation 2020! Sophies button Anirras Button Profile Info Settings Levels this is info page Level 1 : Fire at Home Natural Disasters P L A Y Emergency Message Auxilium I Am Safe 0
CPR Stroke Drowning Choking Hello World from section: %1$d hello world
Info Page: Strings
CPR Strings How to Perform CPR: 1.Call 911 or ask a bystander to call 911 2.Open their airway, to do this you can tilt their head back to slightly lift the chin while they are lying on their back 3.Check for breathing (for no more than 10 seconds), occasional gasping sounds does not mean they are breathing. If there is none, begin CPR 4.Place your hands, one on top of the other, in the middle of the chest. Use your body weight to administer compressions that are at least 2 inches deep and around 100 chest compressions per minute. Push hard and fast. 5.Deliver rescue breaths. With the person\'s head tilted back slightly and the chin lifted, pinch the nose shut and place your mouth over the person\'s mouth to make a complete seal. Blow into the person\'s mouth to make the chest rise. Deliver two rescue breaths, then continue compressions. 6.Continue CPR steps. Keep performing cycles of chest compressions and breathing until the person exhibits signs of life, such as breathing, an AED becomes available, or EMS or a trained medical responder arrives on scene. Note: If the chest does not rise with the initial rescue breath, re-tilt the head before delivering the second breath. If the chest doesn\'t rise with the second breath, the person may be choking. After each subsequent set of 30 chest compressions, and before attempting breaths, look for an object and, if seen, remove it. Note: End the cycles if the scene becomes unsafe or you cannot continueeath, the person may be choking. After each subsequent set of 30 chest compressions, and before attempting breaths, look for an object and, if seen, remove it.
Stroke Strings How to Tell if Someone is Having a Stroke: Follow the acronym FAST. 1. F – Face drooping. Is one side of the person’s face drooping or numb? When he or she smiles, is the smile uneven? 2. A – Arm weakness. Is the person experiencing weakness or numbness in one arm? Have the person raise both arms. Does one of the arms drift downward? 3. S – Speech difficulty. Is the person’s speech suddenly slurred or hard to understand? Is he or she unable to speak? Ask the person to repeat a simple sentence. Can he or she repeat it back? 4. T – Time to call 9–1–1. If any of these symptoms are present, dial 9–1–1 immediately. Check the time so you can report when the symptoms began
Choking Strings What To Do If Someone Is Choking: This is called the 5 on 5 method. Do this if a person can’t talk, laugh, cry, or cough forcefully. 1. Give 5 back blows. Stand to the side and just behind a choking adult. For a child, kneel down behind. Place one arm across the person\'s chest for support. Bend the person over at the waist so that the upper body is parallel with the ground. Deliver five separate back blows between the person\'s shoulder blades with the heel of your hand. 2. Give 5 abdominal thrusts. Perform five abdominal thrusts (also known as the Heimlich maneuver). 3. Alternate between 5 blows and 5 thrusts until the blockage is dislodged.
Drowning Strings What To Do If Someone Has Drowned: (is out of the water but unconscious) 1. Try to wake the casualty. Give them a good shake, or even pinch their earlobe. If they don’t show any signs of consciousness… 2. Lie them on t heir back and tilt their chin and head backwards to help clear their airway. This could be enough to get them to start breathing. Check if they’re breathing by leaning over them and placing your cheek near their mouth. LOOK along their chest as you do this to see if their chest is rising and falling, FEEL for breath on your cheek and LISTEN for breathing sounds. If there is no sign of breath then you should… 3. Give them 5 rescue breaths. Pinch their nose and keep their head tilted back as you breathe into their mouth from yours, making as good a seal as you can with your mouth over theirs. Each breath you give them should last 1 second, and make sure that you take a good deep breath yourself in between each one. These breaths will get valuable oxygen into their lungs, which is particularly important in a drowned casualty. After you’ve done 5 rescue breaths try… 4. CPR.*see CPR page* 5. If you are on your own, then once you’ve done 5 rescue breaths and one minute of CPR you can take the time to call the emergency services. Hopefully you will have helped get some oxygen to their brain. But as soon as you have called for help, then continue: 6. 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths over and over again until they start breathing normally or help arrives (if there’s more than one of you then take it in turns).
You hear gunshots and see a shooter, what should you do? Run and Escape Grab your phone and other belongings Call 911 Hide behind other people
You start running and realize that there are no exits near you, what should you do? Jump in front of the shooter to startle them Maintain eye-contact with the shooter Hide out of the shooter\'s view Try to find your friends or another group of people
The shooter is coming towards you and you can not escape, what should you do? Scream Stay still Fight the shooter aggressively Turn around and hope you are not seen
The shooter falls to the ground, what should you do? Run from the shooter and call 911 Post the story on social media Run from the shooter and call your family Call your best friend
Good Try! Congratulations! Try harder.
You feel an earthquake, what should you do? Run outside Get under a roof Drop to the ground Panic
What should you do next? Cover your neck and head, and get under a table Call your parents Scream for help Hide under a glass table
What should you do next? Hold onto a sturdy object Run for help Call 911 Get under a tree
The earthquake has stopped, what should you do? Scream “Yay” Post the story on social media Call 911 Check for injuries
No one is injured, what should you do? Call to make sure your friends and family are okay Carry on with your day Listen to a radio for emergency updates and reports Call 911
